awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A New Approach to Detrital Provenance Determination: Application of Laser-Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) to the Tourmaline Supergroup Minerals
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding Earth's geological history provides insight into processes that shape our planet and the distribution of economic resources.  However, ancient geological events can be difficult to decipher because their physical presence may be lost to erosion. Fortunately, information on the types and ages of rocks (i.e., their provenance) that were present prior to weathering and erosion are encoded in some minerals that are preserved in sediments and sedimentary rocks.  Tourmaline is one such mineral. It is a key repository of geologic information because it incorporates a wide range of chemical elements that reflect the rock environment in which it forms - that is, it encodes the chemical signature of that rock, similar to a fingerprint. Tourmaline is also a chemically and mechanically resistant mineral that, when weathered out of the rock in which it formed, can become a sand grain that is incorporated into sediments (and rocks). Once it incorporates its original chemical signature, the tourmaline grain stores that signature for millions or billions of years.

This work uses a synergistic approach to decipher former geological events, their record in sediments and rocks, by integrating chemical analyses of the mineral tourmaline using the new technology Laser-Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) with the established technology Electron Microprobe analyses (EMP). Both yield in-situ chemical fingerprints: LIBS is advantageous because it collects signals of all elements and their complexes, including the light elements, and provides relative compositions of elements, while EMP is a mature analytical technique and is used for highly precise and accurate micrometer-scale chemical data for most elements (except light elements H, Li). One goal of this work is to use these complementary techniques to develop robust approaches to provenance determination based on an extensive collection of tourmaline samples of known provenance.  The provenance techniques will be applied, in a case study, to the geologic development of the East Antarctic Mountains (650-480 million years ago). The goal of this case study is to test the efficacy of tourmaline analysis by LIBS and EMP in deciphering complex geologic history of East Antarctic.  This study has two major implications.  First, it will develop new avenues of provenance studies to refine our understanding of Earth history using the widespread mineral tourmaline. An additional societal benefit is the potential to differentiate tourmalines from different gem deposits that command radically different prices.  Samples, data and techniques from this study will be used in both undergraduate and graduate classes at two minority-serving Universities to educate the next generation of geoscientists.  A student exchange between the two universities will broaden their educational and analytical experience, necessary for today?s global workforce. This research team includes two female co-PIs and all PIs serve as mentors to a significant number of women in STEM disciplines.  Collaboration with industry brings together academics and industrial partners including a woman-owned for-profit small business, in addition to collaborations with faculty at another undergraduate-focused university.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Louisiana State University & Agricultural and Mechanical College

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Much of Earth?s geological history is embedded in the chemical signatures of minerals. Such signatures may reveal information on the former pressure-temperature conditions of the rocks and the fluids with which the minerals interacted and the geologic time in which they formed. All of these data contribute to our understanding of Earth's history, the location of economic mineral deposits, and specific past geological events. Developing methods to more fully extract these signatures is optimized when combining new analytical techniques with well-established methods in minerals that record chemical information, but are resistant to physical or chemical weathering.  This project utilizes and establishes that the mineral tourmaline, a chemically diverse and mechanically robust borosilicate mineral, is a key repository of geologic information because it is extremely responsive to the rock environment in which it grows and it imprints chemical information about its original source rock. This chemical fingerprint remains in the mineral when the grain is separated from its original rock - it provides provenance information even over billions of years. The implication is that if you can interpret the chemical data properly using known host rocks you can determine the provenance of tourmaline that is separated from its original host rock as in sand grains or gemstones of uncertain origin. Consequently, a fundamental outcome of this project was a collection of more than 700 samples from known geologic settings and from wide-ranging geographic locations. This a unique sample set of tourmaline that has yielded a number of derivative project results.

This project uses a synergistic approach to decipher embedded chemical information and to interpret this information by chemically analyzing the same tourmaline grains with a relatively new technique, Laser Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) and a well-established technique, electron probe microanalysis (EPMA). Both techniques yield in-situ chemical fingerprints on the mineral: LIBS provides relative compositions of all elements and their complexes, including light elements, while EMP provides highly precise and accurate chemical data (except for many light elements) on smaller spatial scales. To take advantage of this large amount of qualitative data generated, entire sets of LIBS spectra were modeled using multivariate statistical approaches to establish a chemical fingerprinting method to provenance determination using tourmaline. In addition, another outcome was establishment of analytical operating conditions for LIBS to produce statistically robust results and to optimize data quality. These techniques were successfully used to develop matching algorithms for 11 possible host rock lithologies. These procedures were used to constrain provenance in sediments of the Cambrian Ross Orogen of Antarctica and metasedimentary rocks of the Picuris Mountains, New Mexico - both results help refine tectonic interpretations. An allied provenance application is in sourcing the gem copper-bearing tourmaline, all from similar host rocks, to one of four possible geographic sources: two localities in Brazil, one each in Mozambique and Nigeria, using these approaches. This result is of significant economic importance because the Brazilian gems are considerably more expensive than the African gems. These complementary techniques developed during this research refined a robust approach to geologic provenance determinations using the mineral tourmaline.

Societal and broader impacts of the research are many fold. One societal benefit is the ability to distinguish tourmalines from different geographic gem deposits that command radically different prices. A second benefit is that some tourmalines appear to contain chemical signatures of ore deposits. Additionally, samples and data acquired for this study were used in two undergraduate course-embedded research projects to help educate the next generation of geoscientists. This research project was the focus of three MS thesis and provided opportunities for eight undergraduates, seven from underrepresented groups, to undertake research during their studies. Such research enhances their analytical, quantitative and critical thinking skills needed for today's workforce. Five of these undergraduates and two M.S. students presented their research results at conferences, offering the opportunities to hone their written, oral and visual communication skills, necessary in today's global workplace. The research team included two female co-PIs and worked with a woman-owned for-profit small business. 


Last Modified: 09/28/2022
Modified by: Barbara L Dutrow

Image

    Barbara L. Dutrow
